entry.title: Ukraine Hit by Deadliest Single Russian Attack on Civilians in Weeks
entry.content: Russian strikes killed at least 10 people in eastern Ukraine, as President Vladimir Putin said he was preparing for a long, protracted conflict in the country.

entry.title: Peru's New President Faces Same Turmoil That Ousted Predecessor
entry.content: Dina Boluarte, the country’s first female president, began her first full day as president after Pedro Castillo was ousted by Congress.

entry.title: Ukraine Says Western Allies Shouldn't Fear Russia Falling Apart
entry.content: Ukraine’s foreign minister defended Kyiv’s right to strike targets on Russian soil and vowed that Ukraine would never accept a peace settlement that leaves occupied lands, including Crimea, under Moscow’s control.

entry.title: The Five-Year Engineering Feat Germany Pulled Off in Months
entry.content: Europe is racing to build natural-gas facilities to keep its economy afloat. If it fails to shore up its energy grid, governments might have to ration fuel this winter. “This project is really a race against time,” said one manager.

entry.title: Police Seize Weapons in Far-Right German Coup-Plot Investigation
entry.content: The group hoarded weapons, subscribed to esoteric conspiracies and commissioned occultists to help plan a coup, officials say.

entry.title: Russians March on Foot to Advance in Eastern Ukraine Battle
entry.content: The battle for Bakhmut has become a bloodbath for both sides as Russia steps up its attempts to take what used to be a quaint, tree-lined city.

entry.title: South Korea Orders Truckers Back to Work as Labor Tensions Rise Globally
entry.content: President Yoon widened the scope of a back-to-work order to include the steel and petrochemical industries, after issuing a similar order for the cement sector last week.

entry.title: Argentina Binges on the World Cup to Forget Soaring Inflation and Unrest
entry.content: During the monthlong tournament, protesters stay home during matches, people celebrate in the street and economic woes take a back seat.
